sen.j: 京都霊山護国神社（きょうとりょうぜんごこくじんじゃ）は、京都府京都市東山区にある神社である。
sen.e: Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 1862年、時衆霊山派の正法寺の朱印地 のなかの神道葬祭場霊明社において有志者による神葬祭が行われた。
sen.e: In 1862, a Shinto funeral was held by supporters at the Reimei-sha Shrine Shinto funeral place within the territory authorized to be held by the Jishu Ryozan-branch's Shobo-ji Temple.
In 1862, a Shinto funeral was held by supporters at the Reimei-sha Shrine Shinto funeral place within the territory authorized to be held by the Jishu Ryozan-branch's Shobo-ji Temple.
In 1862, a Shinto funeral was held by supporters at the Reimei-sha Shrine Shinto funeral place within the territory authorized to be held by the Jishu Ryozan-school's Shobo-ji Temple.

sen.j: 祭神は菊理媛神・速玉男命・事解男命の3神（他に相殿3神）。
sen.e: The three deities Kukurihimeno Kami, Hayatamaono Mikoto and Kotosakaono Mikoto are enshrined (and three other deities within the aidono building).
The three deities Kukurihimeno Kami, Hayatamaono Mikoto and Kotosakaono Mikoto are enshrined (and three other deities within the aidono building).
The three deities Kukurihimeno Kami, Hayatamaono Mikoto and Kotosakaono Mikoto are enshrined (and three other deities within the aidono building).

sen.j: 1868年（明治元年）5月10日、明治天皇から明治維新を目前にして倒れた志士たち（天誅組など）の御霊を奉祀するために、京都・東山の霊山の佳域社を創建せよとの詔・御沙汰が発せられた。
sen.e: On the 10th day of the 5th month of 1868, an imperial edict was made ordering a shrine to be established on Ryozan in Higashiyama, Kyoto to enshrine the spirits of pro-imperialists (such as the Tenchu-gumi) who were killed prior to Meiji Restoration.

On the 10th day of the 5th month of 1868, an imperial edict was made ordering a shrine to be established on Ryozan in Higashiyama, Kyoto to enshrine the spirits of pro-imperialists (such as the Tenchu-gumi) who were killed prior to Meiji Restoration.

On June 29, 1868, an imperial edict was made ordering a shrine to be established on Ryozan in Higashiyama, Kyoto to enshrine the spirits of pro-imperialists (such as the Tenchu-gumi) who were killed prior to Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: それに感激した京都の公家や山口藩・高知藩・福井藩・鳥取藩・熊本藩などの諸藩が相計らい京都の霊山の山頂にそれぞれの祠宇を建立したのが神社創建のはじまりであり、日本初の招魂社である。
sen.e: This inspired Kyoto court nobles and lords of various domains including Yamaguchi, Kochi, Fukui, Tottori and Kumamoto to come together and construct shrines at the peak of Ryozan and it is these shrines that were the beginning of Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine - Japan's first Shokonsha (Shinto shrine enshrining the spirits of those who were martyred for the nation).

This inspired Kyoto court nobles and lords of various domains including Yamaguchi, Kochi, Fukui, Tottori and Kumamoto to come together and construct shrines at the peak of Ryozan and it is these shrines that were the beginning of Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine - Japan's first Shokonsha (Shinto shrine enshrining the spirits of those who were martyred for the nation).

This inspired Kyoto court nobles and lords of various domains including Yamaguchi, Kochi, Fukui, Tottori and Kumamoto to come together and construct shrines at the peak of Ryozan and it is these shrines that were the beginning of Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine - Japan's first Shokonsha (Shinto shrine enshrining the spirits of those who were martyred for the nation).

sen.j: 靖国神社より古い歴史を持つ。
sen.e: Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine has a history far longer than that of Yasukuni-jinja Shrine.
Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine has a history far longer than that of Yasukuni-jinja Shrine.
Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine has a history far longer than that of Yasukuni-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 当初の社号を霊山官祭招魂社と称し、社格にはとくに『官祭社』に列し国費で営繕されてきた。
sen.e: The shrine's original name was "Ryozan Kansai Shokonsha Shrine" and it was ranked as a "Kansaisha" and maintained at the state's expense.
The shrine's original name was "Ryozan Kansai Shokonsha Shrine" and it was ranked as a "Kansaisha" and maintained at the state's expense.
The shrine's original name was Ryozan Kansai Shokonsha Shrine and it was ranked as a "Kansaisha" and maintained at the state's expense.

sen.j: 1936年（昭和11年）、支那事変をきっかけとして国難に殉じた京都府出身者の英霊を手厚く祀ろうという運動がおき、霊山官祭招魂社造営委員会が組織され、境内を拡大して新たに社殿を造営した。
sen.e: In 1936, the China Incident (Shina Jihen) sparked the move toward reverently enshrining the souls of persons from Kyoto who sacrificed themselves for the nation, leading to the formation of the Ryozan Kansai Shokonsha Shrine Erection Committee that worked to expand the precinct and construct new shrine buildings.

In 1936, the China Incident (Shina Jihen) sparked the move toward reverently enshrining the souls of persons from Kyoto who sacrificed themselves for the nation, leading to the formation of the Ryozan Kansai Shokonsha Shrine Erection Committee that worked to expand the precinct and construct new shrine buildings.

In 1936, the China Incident sparked the move toward reverently enshrining the souls of persons from Kyoto who sacrificed themselves for the nation, leading to the formation of the Ryozan Kansai Shokonsha Shrine Erection Committee that worked to expand the precinct and construct new shrine buildings.

sen.j: 1939年（昭和14年）4月1日、内務大臣布告によって現在の社号である京都霊山護国神社と改称された。
sen.e: The name of the shrine was changed to its present name of "Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine" following a declaration made by the Home Minister on April 1st 1939.
The name of the shrine was changed to its present name of "Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine" following a declaration made by the Home Minister on April 1st 1939.
The name of the shrine was changed to its present name of Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine following a declaration made by the Home Minister on April 1, 1939.

sen.j: 戦後は宗教法人・神社本庁の包括下におかれ、国家の手を離れた。
sen.e: After the Second World War, the shrine separated from state control to become a religious corporation and part of the Association of Shinto Shrines.
After the Second World War, the shrine separated from state control to become a religious corporation and part of the Association of Shinto Shrines.
After the Second World War, the shrine separated from state control to become a religious corporation and part of the Association of Shinto Shrines.

sen.j: GHQ占領下においては京都神社に改称していたが、独立後は元の社名に復した。
sen.e: During the GHQ (General Headquarters) occupation period, the shrine's name was changed to "Kyoto-jinja Shrine" but the previous name was restored following independence.
During the GHQ (General Headquarters) occupation period, the shrine's name was changed to "Kyoto-jinja Shrine" but the previous name was restored following independence.
During the GHQ (General Headquarters) occupation period, the shrine's name was changed to Kyoto-jinja Shrine but the previous name was restored following independence.

sen.j: 1970年（昭和45年）境内に明治維新関係の資料を展示する「霊山歴史館」が開館した。
sen.e: The "Ryozen Rekishikan"(museum) was opened within the precinct in 1970 to exhibit historical materials relating to the Meiji Restoration.
The "Ryozen Rekishikan"(museum) was opened within the precinct in 1970 to exhibit historical materials relating to the Meiji Restoration.
The 'Ryozen Rekishikan' (museum) was opened within the precinct in 1970 to exhibit historical materials relating to the Meiji Restoration.

sen.j: 2002年（平成14年）神社本庁との包括関係を解消。
sen.e: In 2002, the shrine cancelled its relationship with the Association of Shinto Shrines.
In 2002, the shrine cancelled its relationship with the Association of Shinto Shrines.
In 2002, the shrine cancelled its relationship with the Association of Shinto Shrines.

sen.j: 祭神の中には京都で暗殺された坂本龍馬も含まれており、境内に銅像が作られているほか、誕生日であり命日でもある11月15日には、龍馬の遺徳を偲び霊を慰める龍馬祭が行われる（誕生日・命日は本来は旧暦11月15日だが、祭は新暦11月15日に行われる）。
sen.e: The deities enshrined at Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine include Ryoma SAKAMOTO who was assassinated in Kyoto, with a bronze statue of him standing at the shrine and the Ryoma-sai Festival held on the anniversary of both his birth and death on November 15th of each year to honor his memory and comfort his soul (his birth and death originally took place on November 15th of the old calendar but the festival is held on November 15th of the Gregorian calendar).

The deities enshrined at Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine include Ryoma SAKAMOTO who was assassinated in Kyoto, with a bronze statue of him standing at the shrine and the Ryoma-sai Festival held on the anniversary of both his birth and death on November 15th of each year to honor his memory and comfort his soul (his birth and death originally took place on November 15th of the old calendar but the festival is held on November 15th of the Gregorian calendar).

The deities enshrined at Kyoto Ryozen Gokoku-jinja Shrine include Ryoma SAKAMOTO who was assassinated in Kyoto, with a bronze statue of him standing at the shrine and the Ryoma-sai Festival held on the anniversary of both his birth and death on November 15 of each year to honor his memory and comfort his soul (his birth and death originally took place on November 15 of the old calendar but the festival is held on November 15 of the Gregorian calendar).

sen.j: 龍馬のほかに、中岡慎太郎、頼三樹三郎、梅田雲浜、吉村寅太郎、平野国臣らが祭神として祀られている。
sen.e: As well as Ryoma SAKAMOTO, Shintaro NAKAOKA, Mikisaburo RAI, Unpin UMEDA, Torataro YOSHIMURA and Kuniomi HIRANO are also enshrined.
As well as Ryoma SAKAMOTO, Shintaro NAKAOKA, Mikisaburo RAI, Unpin UMEDA, Torataro YOSHIMURA and Kuniomi HIRANO are also enshrined.
As well as Ryoma SAKAMOTO, Shintaro NAKAOKA, Mikisaburo RAI, Unpin UMEDA, Torataro YOSHIMURA and Kuniomi HIRANO are also enshrined.

sen.j: 歳旦祭 - 1月1日-1月3日
sen.e: Saitan-sai (New Year Celemony): January 1st-3rd
sen.cmt: 歳旦祭→Saitansai (Saitansai is a Shinto ritual to mark the beginning of New Year, followed by a special sharing of sake (rice wine) in the barrel and a mochi (rice cake) pounding ceremony)[www.tourism.metro.tokyo.jp/english/.../3.html]
sen.e: Saitan-sai (New Year Celemony): January 1st-3rd
Saitan-sai (New Year Ceremony): January 1-3

sen.j: 紀元節 - 2月11日
sen.e: Kigensetsu (National Foundation Day): February 11th
sen.cmt: 紀元節→Kigensetsu (the National Foundation Day) (the day commemorating the ascension to the throne of the first emperor, Jimmu) [www.meijigakuin.ac.jp/~ascj/2009/.../2009-04.html]
sen.e: Kigensetsu (National Foundation Day): February 11th
Kigensetsu (National Foundation Day): February 11

sen.j: 春季例大祭 - 4月28日
sen.e: Shunki Reitaisai (Spring Festival): April 28th
Shunki Reitaisai (Spring Festival): April 28th
Shunki Reitaisai (Spring Festival): April 28

sen.j: 大祓
sen.e: Oharae (great purification)
Oharae (great purification)

sen.j: みたま祭 - 8月13日-8月16日
sen.e: Mitama matsuri (Soul Festival): August 13th-16th
Mitama matsuri (Soul Festival): August 13th-16th
Mitama matsuri (Soul Festival): August 13-16

sen.j: 龍馬祭 - 11月15日
sen.e: Ryoma-sai (Ryoma SAKAMOTO memorial festival): November 15th
Ryoma-sai (Ryoma SAKAMOTO memorial festival): November 15th
Ryoma-sai (Ryoma SAKAMOTO memorial festival): November 15

sen.j: 秋期例大祭 - 10月14日
sen.e: Shuki Reitaisai (Autumn Festival): October 14th
Shuki Reitaisai (Autumn Festival): October 14th

sen.j: 天長祭 - 12月23日
sen.e: Tencho-sai (Emperor's Birthday): 23rd December
Tencho-sai (Emperor's Birthday): 23rd December
Tencho-sai (Emperor's Birthday): December 23

sen.j: 1997年、太平洋戦争を記念した「昭和の杜」が設けられた。
sen.e: The "Showa no Mori" was completed in 1997 as a memorial to the Pacific War.
The "Showa no Mori" was completed in 1997 as a memorial to the Pacific War.
The 'Showa no Mori' was completed in 1997 as a memorial to the Pacific War.

sen.j: 境内にはインド独立50周年を記念し、極東国際軍事裁判にて、ただ一人、被告全員の無罪を唱えたインド代表判事ラダ・ビノード・パールの顕彰碑などが建立されている。
sen.e: The 50th anniversary of the independence of India is commemorated within the precinct and there is a monument honoring the Indian judge Radha Binod Pal, the lone justice on the International Military Tribunal for the Far East to find all the defendants not guilty.
sen.cmt: 極東国際軍事裁判→Kyokuto Kokusai Gunji Saiban (International Military Tribunal for the Far East)[catalog.lawrence.lib.ks.us:90/search~S2?/]
sen.e: The 50th anniversary of the independence of India is commemorated within the precinct and there is a monument honoring the Indian judge Radha Binod Pal, the lone justice on the International Military Tribunal for the Far East to find all the defendants not guilty.

The 50th anniversary of the independence of India is commemorated within the precinct and there is a monument honoring the Indian judge Radha Binod Pal, the lone justice on the International Military Tribunal for the Far East to find all the defendants not guilty.

sen.j: 西日本旅客鉄道京都駅、京阪電気鉄道四条駅 (京阪)、阪急電鉄河原町駅 (京都府)より、京都市営バス祇園方面行き「東山安井」下車徒歩10分。
sen.e: 10 minutes walk from the JR West Kyoto Station, Keihan Electric Railways Shijo Station (Keihan), Hankyu Corporation Kawaramachi Station (Kyoto Prefecture) or the "Higashiyama Yasui" bus stop on the Kyoto City Bus route to Gion.

10 minutes walk from the JR West Kyoto Station, Keihan Electric Railways Shijo Station (Keihan), Hankyu Corporation Kawaramachi Station (Kyoto Prefecture) or the "Higashiyama Yasui" bus stop on the Kyoto City Bus route to Gion.
